channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Elections 2021: Conservatives take Hartlepool from Labour in by-election
item.description: Hartlepool elects a Conservative MP for the first time since the constituency's creation, after Jill Mortimer wins by-election.

item.title: Elections 2021: Tory gains as first English councils declare
item.description: But many of the local election results are still to come, with further results expected throughout the weekend.

item.title: Turner Prize honours art collectives who 'inspire change'
item.description: After a year of closed galleries, the 2021 nominees are all groups who have all "inspired change".

item.title: Covid: Concern increases over India variant in UK
item.description: Health experts want the version B.1.617.2 to be made a "variant of concern", the BBC has been told.

item.title: Holiday costs to jump in summer, warns travel boss
item.description: Travel will be more expensive as airlines cannot afford to bring many planes back into service.

item.title: Plastic bag charge to double to 10p in all shops in England
item.description: The price rise for single-use bags will be extended to all businesses in England from 21 May.

item.title: Julia James: Police don't know weapon used to kill PCSO
item.description: Kent's chief constable says police still have no motive or suspect for the murder of Julia James.

item.title: Big Chinese rocket segment set to fall to Earth
item.description: Tracking radars are following closely the gradual fall to Earth of a large Chinese rocket vehicle.

item.title: Rare fish set for return to River Severn breeding grounds
item.description: One of the UK's rarest fish is set to benefit from a conservation project to unlock the River Severn.

item.title: 'They have guns but we have people': Inside Myanmar's Spring Revolution
item.description: A musician and his sister in Yangon have been filming for the BBC in Myanmar in the aftermath of a coup.

item.title: The Papers: 'Smash and crab' and cheap tests for British travellers
item.description: Friday's front pages focus on the protest by French fishermen in Jersey waters over post-Brexit rights.

item.title: Covid and pregnancy - should you get the vaccine?
item.description: As the Covid vaccine is rolled out to younger age groups, BBC News looks at what it means for anyone expecting a baby.

item.title: Grand Canyon lottery to kill bison gathers 45,000 entries
item.description: A chance to shoot a rare buffalo in the famed US National Park drew over 45,000 applicants.

item.title: Train named after Great Escape hero who 'inspired Steve McQueen'
item.description: Wing Cdr Ken Rees is said to have inspired Steve McQueen's character in the classic film.

item.title: The Coronation Street storyline based on a real-life murder
item.description: The plot is drawn from the killing of Sophie Lancaster in 2007, who was murdered for being a goth.

item.title: Team GB & ParalympicsGB unveil kit for delayed Tokyo Games
item.description: Team GB and ParalympicsGB athletes will wear a kit that "represents unity in diversity" at the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games.

item.title: Animal rescuers use mother duck YouTube video to save ducklings
item.description: Rescuers used footage of a mother duck's call to lure the young birds to safety at a busy roadside.

item.title: SpaceX: The rocky road to a smooth rocket landing
item.description: As the latest Starship prototype completes a successful ascent and landing, here's its route to success.

item.title: Disability and domestic abuse: 'No-one knows what is happening behind those walls'
item.description: As cases of domestic abuse rise during lockdown, disabled victims can face particular challenges to escape their abusers.

item.title: Taiwan: Judo class puts a seven-year-old in a coma
item.description: The incident in Taiwan shows a tendency to allow child abuse in the name of discipline, experts say.

item.title: Eurovision's noisy fans are back despite Dutch pandemic
item.description: It's Europe's most popular cultural event and the Netherlands will host it despite battling a third Covid wave.

item.title: Covid-19 vaccines: Why some African states have leftover doses
item.description: African countries struggled to get vaccines, but now several of them have thousands of expired doses.

item.title: 'It hurts to look at home': Heartbroken Indians help from abroad
item.description: Seeing loved ones suffering in India, millions of families are trying to do their best from afar.

item.title: Taking an invention from idea to the marketplace
item.description: Lockdown spurred many people to invent new products, but how did they get to market?

item.title: Rag 'n' Bone Man talks about his struggles with fame
item.description: Singer-songwriter Rag 'n' Bone Man says he wanted his friends to rescue him from red carpets.

item.title: Covid: The vaccine patent row explained
item.description: The US says it supports a temporary lift on vaccine patents, but some countries have pushed back.

item.title: Jersey fishing: What's the row between UK and France about?
item.description: French fishing boats protest at the port of St Helier, in dispute over access to waters around the island.

item.title: No full-time return to the office for over a million
item.description: Almost all of 50 big UK firms tell the BBC staff will divide their time between home and office in future.

item.title: Byron burger death: No damages payout for Owen Carey's family
item.description: Owen Carey's family officially launch their campaign for a law change following his death in 2017.

item.title: India Covid: How bad is the second wave?
item.description: There are signs infections have slowed in some regions - but is India past the worst?

item.title: Covid: Black leaders fear racist past feeds mistrust in vaccine
item.description: Mistrust and inequality may explain why vaccine take-up is lower in the black community, say campaigners.

item.title: Safe Sweden faces up to wave of women's killings
item.description: A spate of deaths reignites a debate about domestic violence in a country praised for gender equality.

item.title: Lelush: How a sulky Russian model became China's slacker icon
item.description: Getting trapped in a boy band reality TV contest was just the start of Lelush's unlikely journey.

item.title: While She Sleeps: Why I spend big subscribing to my favourite band
item.description: Sheffield band While She Sleeps say they've created 'a sustainable model' for the music industry.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Families stranded in Pakistan, India and Bangladesh
item.description: The cost of hotel quarantine in the UK is too high for some families, who have had to delay their return instead.

item.title: Roma 3-2 Man Utd (5-8 on aggregate): 'Faith in Ole Gunnar Solskjaer close to being rewarded'
item.description: It would seem automatic for Manchester United to reward manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer with a new contract after taking them to the Europa League final, says Simon Stone.

item.title: Arsenal 'devastated' by Europa League exit but where does club go now?
item.description: BBC Sport gathers reaction from the manager, players, pundits and more to gauge the mood after a disastrous night for Arsenal - and asks where the club goes from here.

item.title: 'He was a much better dad than golfer' - Javier Ballesteros reflects on Seve's death 10 years ago
item.description: Javier Ballesteros, the son of iconic Spanish golfer Seve Ballesteros, speaks to BBC Sport on the 10th anniversary of his father's death.

item.title: Matt Dawson column: Warren Gatland has got Lions selection right - as always
item.description: Three-time Lion Matt Dawson says head coach Warren Gatland has once again got his selection right for this summer's South Africa tour.

item.title: 2021 elections: What are the results in my area?
item.description: National elections in Scotland and Wales and local elections in England took place on 6 May 2021.

item.title: Election 2021: When will we find out the results?
item.description: Millions of people have marked their ballots, but there could be a long wait this year.

item.title: Elections 2021: How to follow the results on the BBC
item.description: Find out how to keep up to date with live election results on TV, radio, online and on social media.

item.title: What to expect in Scottish election
item.description: Scots have cast their votes, but they will not be counted until Friday and Saturday - when will the outcome be known?

item.title: Elections 2021: Dogs at polling stations
item.description: Voters are heading to the polls in England, Scotland and Wales - and so are their canine companions.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Scotland awaits results
item.description: Ballots will be counted over two days with the final result for 129 seats at Holyrood expected on Saturday.

item.title: Elections 2021: How the BBC reports polling day
item.description: The BBC is not allowed to report details of campaigning while the polls are open.

item.title: When can I holiday abroad, and which countries will be on the green list?
item.description: A new "traffic light" system for travel will classify countries as green, amber or red.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: How many cases in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Northern Ireland is the latest part of the UK to lift some of the restrictions designed to stop the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: The world is carefully monitoring Covid for mutations that help it spread better or resist vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: What are my money-back rights for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays may soon be possible, but what are my refund and travel insurance rights?

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Rules on hugging and social distancing in England are being reviewed.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 40 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Northern Ireland follows England, Scotland and Wales in allowing venues to reopen outdoors.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: What is the stamp duty holiday and when will it finish?
